title: Scotch Eggs Recipe
description: Scotch eggs are soft-boiled eggs wrapped in sausage, coated in bread crumbs, and fried for a delicious British pub favorite or portable picnic treat.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Breakfast and Brunch Eggs Scotch Eggs 4.7 (155) 129 Reviews 51 Photos Scotch eggs are soft-boiled eggs wrapped in sausage and bread crumbs, deep-fried for a delicious savory treat. They're a British pub favorite, perfect for family occasions or picnics. We like to make these on Christmas Eve served on a bed of lettuce with sliced tomatoes and mustard for garnish. Submitted by Chasity LeGrand Updated on April 18, 2025 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 51 51 51 51 Prep Time: 20 mins Cook Time: 30 mins Total Time: 50 mins Servings: 4 Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe Enjoy traditional Scotch eggs in the comfort of your own kitchen with this unforgettable recipe.  What Is a Scotch Egg? A Scotch egg is a soft-boiled egg that has been wrapped in pork sausage, breaded, and deep-fried or baked. Despite its name, this likely has English (not Scottish) origins. Scotch eggs are commonly served cold at picnics in the U.K. and packaged Scotch eggs are widely available in British supermarkets, corner shops, and gas stations. How to Make Scotch Eggs You’ll find a full, step-by-step recipe below — but here’s a brief overview of what you can expect when you make Scotch eggs at home:  Boil, cool, and peel the eggs. Flatten the sausage, make patties, and wrap the patties around each egg.Lightly flour the sausage layer, then coat with the beaten egg. Roll in bread crumbs.Deep fry the sausage-covered eggs until they’re golden brown.  How to Serve Scotch Eggs Scotch eggs can be served as an appetizer, snack, or side dish. It could even work as a light meal with a fresh side salad! You might also consider pairing it with a dipping sauce for extra flavor or something with a British flair, such as Basic Mashed Potatoes or British Baked Beans.  Can You Make Scotch Eggs Ahead of Time? If you’d like to make these Scotch eggs one day in advance, boil the eggs and wrap them in sausage. Instead of immediately cooking, store the prepared eggs in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Fry them immediately before you plan to serve them.  How to Store Scotch Eggs Allow the Scotch eggs to cool completely, then transfer them to an airtight container lined with paper towels to soak up extra moisture. Seal the container and store in the fridge for up to three days.  Can You Freeze Scotch Eggs? While you can freeze these homemade Scotch eggs for up to three months, we don’t recommend it unless it’s absolutely necessary. The crispy crust will likely become mushy during the freezing and thawing process.  Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise “Fun recipe,” according to loriaprn. “Easier to make than I thought it would be. My family loved them. Quality sausage is important. I added a little onion powder to my bread crumbs. Yum!” “Everyone loved these served on lettuce and fresh tomato,” says Heather G. “I even caught my hubby and 2 kids eating the leftover scotch eggs cold the next morning.” “So easy to make and tastes amazing,” raves Brandy Pallares. “I had never even had a Scotch egg before trying this recipe. I made a quick dip for them that sent it over the top! Mix a half cup of mayo with several dashes of Texas Pete hot sauce.” Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings 1 quart oil for frying 4 large eggs 2 pounds bulk pork sausage 1 cup all-purpose flour 4 large eggs, beaten 4 cups dried bread crumbs, seasoned Directions Gather all ingredients. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Heat oil in a deep-fryer to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck Place eggs in a saucepan and cover with water. Bring to boil. Cover, remove from heat, and let eggs sit in hot water for 10 to 12 minutes. Remove from hot water, cool, and peel. Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck Flatten sausage and make a patty to surround each egg. Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck Very lightly flour the outer sausage layer then coat with beaten egg. Roll in bread crumbs to cover evenly. Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck Deep-fry prepared eggs in hot oil until golden brown while making sure each side is well cooked. Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck Bake in the preheated oven for 10 minutes. Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck Cut in half and serve. Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck Enjoy! Add Your Photo Photos of Scotch Eggs 01 of 51 Photo by  Allrecipes / Julia Hartbeck 02 of 51 Photo by  LivelyCow1858 04/18/2025 Worth the effort Great flavors I only steamed my eggs for 8 minutes because I wanted jammy centres. Took around 5 minutes in the oil to get them browned and then a quick finish off in the oven to make sure the sausage is cooked. Delicious! 03 of 51 Photo by  BraveChip4323 09/03/2023 I loved my Scotch egg. Only made one. It was about the size of a softball. And I ate the WHOLE thing. It was my first but most definitely won't be my last. The recipe was easy to follow and the addition of the video was great. Thanks Chastity. 04 of 51 Photo by  Lisa 04/20/2022 Omg! I had never heard of them before and twice in one week they were mentioned in two different shows. I had to try so i googled and used this recipe. I did cheat a little and used Jimmy Deans original because it was already seasoned and not in casings. It was so easy and Delicious! The egg was perfect and with the sausage and breading it was just over the top! My very picky husband loved it! I'll be making them again. Tip: Go the extra mile and make a mustard sauce. Not really needed but its so darn tasty 😋 05 of 51 Photo by  Nina Greipel 05/19/2020 I did mine in my airfryer and now think they would be better fried in oil and baked. Was my first time and maybe I'll try em again. 06 of 51 Photo by  amanda 03/19/2020 07 of 51 Photo by  Megan Kasperitis 12/22/2019 I will definitely be making this again. I would however do a few things differently next time. I used 6 eggs instead of 4. (My eggs were kinda small, if I were to use large eggs, the recipe probably won't make 6) I only used 1 8 oz box of bread crumbs and had lots of extra. I also had to add more oil when frying and baked them for about 4-5 extra mins to make sure they were really cooked in the center. My family LOVED them!! 08 of 51 Photo by  Ben Lockett 08/15/2019 09 of 51 Photo by  clanmac5 03/20/2019 Family loved them! 10 of 51 Photo by  Don Boutwell-Olson 03/14/2019 Perfect recipe. I will note that the ingredients are enough for waaaay more than 4 eggs.
